A law of composition on a set $M$ is a map from $M \times M$ to $M$. It is characterized by the assignment $(a, b) \longmapsto a \cdot b$ for $(a, b) \in M \times M$, and in many cases, the image of a given pair $(a, b)$ is written as a "product" $a \cdot b$ or $ab$.
A law of composition on a set $M$ is commutative if $ab = ba$ for all elements $a, b \in M$.
Does the concept of a/an Law of Composition need to be defined for a definition of a/an Commutative Law to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of the Commutative Law explicitly relies on the concept of a law of composition. The Commutative Law states that a law of composition on a set $M$ is commutative if $ab = ba$ for all elements $a, b \\$in M$. This definition presupposes the existence of a law of composition, as it refers to the operation $ab$ which is defined under the law of composition. Without the concept of a law of composition, the operation $ab$ would not be defined, and thus the statement $ab = ba$ would be meaningless. Therefore, the concept of a law of composition is necessary for the definition of the Commutative Law to make sense.
